data.title: Travis: Add clang-format test to ensure code quality
data.body:
If the commit(s) produce a diff with clang-format 3.9, the test fails.

My script is a bit quick and dirty but seems to work. We'll improve it little by little ;)

data.title: DAE material import issue
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
3.0 alpha

**Issue description:**
I have a mesh in blender with material called "VertexColor"
In godot I have a material called "VertexColor.tres"
I place my dae mesh in the godot project, it auto imports. But it does not apply that material.
It would be useful to have this automatically apply the material to the mesh, to save having to make an instance of each new mesh just for the sake of applying a material.

data.title: Input: bind parse_input_event()
data.body:
When using `get_tree().input_event(ev)`, the engine will JUST send the event down the SceneTree.
However, you won't get any of the benefits of the Input singleton:
- No InputMap actions will be emitted
- The internal input state won't be modified, so methods like `Input.get_mouse_pos()` or `Input.is_joy_button_pressed` won't return the expected output after sending the event.

This is fixed by using `Input.parse_input_event(ev)` instead.
I guess we'll also have to update the docs to reflect that this is the preferred method of sending custom InputEvents.

data.title: Input: bind parse_input_event() [2.1]
data.body:
When using `get_tree().input_event(ev)`, the engine will JUST send the event down the SceneTree.
However, you won't get any of the benefits of the Input singleton:
- No InputMap actions will be emitted
- The internal input state won't be modified, so methods like `Input.get_mouse_pos()` or `Input.is_joy_button_pressed` won't return the expected output after sending the event.

This is fixed by using `Input.parse_input_event(ev)` instead.
I guess we'll also have to update the docs to reflect that this is the preferred method of sending custom InputEvents.

data.title: Shader language now recognizes return statements in functions
data.body: But shader functions still don't work because of an issue with the gles3 compiler.

data.title: Idea: make math functions work on vectors
data.body:
It would be nice and efficient to be able to use math functions (`clamp`, `max`, `sin` etc) also on Vector2 and Vector3 types, like in GLSL.

So instead of writing this:
```gdscript
	var turn_max = Vector2(deg2rad(turn_max_deg.x), deg2rad(turn_max_deg.y))
```
We could write simply this:
```gdscript
	var turn_max = deg2rad(turn_max_deg)
```
Which is also faster to execute due to DRY-ness and the possibility for component-wise operations to be executed natively ;)

Another example:
```gdscript
	var turn_max = Vector2(deg2rad(turn_max_deg.x), deg2rad(turn_max_deg.y))
	_turn_cmd = Vector2(clamp(mouse_cmd.x, -turn_max.x, turn_max.x), \
                            clamp(mouse_cmd.y, -turn_max.y, turn_max.y))
```
Becomes:
```gdscript
	var turn_max = deg2rad(turn_max_deg)
	_turn_cmd = clamp(turn_cmd, -turn_max, turn_max)
```

data.title: Expose call_multilevel to scripting
data.body:
I'm working on the framework of my game in Godot, and I use script inheritance, and function overriding a lot. And in order to call a function both in the children and the parent scripts, you would have to use `call_multilevel`, which is not yet exposed to GDScript.
I was about to make a PR, but then I thought it would be better to first make sure others would need this too

data.title: Dedicated material editor
data.body:
With Godot 3 support for PBR materials, being able to create, edit, visualize materials and shaders will become much more relevant than what it is now.

In the current version, working a lot in materials and shaders feels cramped due to the interface of the editor. There are too many panels and divisions, especially when you are working in the visual graph editor (regardless of being able to zoom or not).

I'd like to propose for consideration a better UI for a dedicated material/shader editor, much like UE4 has. Could be a dedicated window, or a "editor view"(not sure if this is the right term), much like we have now 2d/3d/script/asset lib.

![maxresdefault](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1642015/24072128/b0e3a6f6-0bd9-11e7-9307-8660976296e8.jpg)

From this material editor, we should be able to create and save new materials or shaders, without having to select or create any object first, as well as open previously saved materials to view and edit.

Having a dedicated and improved preview pane would also be great. It could allow to quickly view textures, but also to preview the material in a small 3d window (which would allow for different kinds of preview objects like cube, sphere, plane).

Anyone willing to discuss this further? :)

data.title: InputMap: Rename joypad button "PS X" to "PS Cross". [2.1]
InputMap: Rename joypad button "PS X" to "PS Cross".
X11: Don't reset mouse cursor theme.
data.body:
On KDE (and possibly others) the "default" cursor theme is actually some system default, not the one you've set in the desktop setting.
This was especially annoying when using a white cursor, as Godot would then reset back to a dark one.
In my case it was also keeping the cursor from changing its shape.

data.title: Why godot has no api?
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
all/all

**Issue description:**
Why godot has no api?

Since godot has no api, every project that wants to use godot functionality 
has to write/generate its own godot api, or as in 2nd project (re)write godot fuctionality.

Wouldnt it be simpler to provide an api thats able, to pass dll border?
I am not talkig about one that only supports godot-reflection-systems funcs,
because for example the visual server is not present there.
Also im wondering why godot is not "modularised" since for example visual servers api would support it.

godotCore.dll, godotScenes.dll, visualServer.dll, somesound.dll
godotEditor.exe, godotGame.exe

this would provide much more functionality:
1. One still could statically link into 1 godot.exe file if wanted ( but why :) )
2. It would make the mentioned projects much more easier.
3. (Automated) testing would be much easier, (a small c++ or c# test-program. that doesnt "pollute"
    the godot.exe
4. no more need to always compile whole godot, just compile your module (dll, so, a) 
    with your preferred build system. 
5. no need to integrate a programming language into godot, 
    because its easy to integrate godot into the language (if it supports c integration) like c#,...

and much more :)

**Link to minimal example project:**
https://github.com/GodotNativeTools/dlscript_module
https://github.com/neikeq/GodotSharp

And that's cool.

data.title: [TRACKER] Editor packaging issues
data.body:
This issue tracks possible editor packaging improvements and bugs.

- [ ] Godot as flatpak runtime (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/5597)
- [ ] Building AppImages for Godot editor and (maybe) games (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/6681)
- [ ] Provide Windows installers for the Godot editor (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/8057)
- [ ] Provide macOS .dmg images for the Godot editor (https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/8058)

data.title: Provide macOS .dmg images for the Godot editor
data.body:
Official Godot releases could be bundled in `.dmg` images. It allows for a fancier installation interface as seen in [this blog post](https://asmaloney.com/2013/07/howto/packaging-a-mac-os-x-application-using-a-dmg/). It may also be more familiar than extracting a `.zip` file, at least for some users.

Some nice design for the install background is needed too.

Just like for Windows, providing guidance or scripts for packaging Godot projects for macOS may be useful.

data.title: Provide Windows installers for the Godot editor
data.body:
Windows installers will allow for a better out-of-the-box user experience, providing things such as start menu entries, easier installation and uninstall procedures, built-in export templates, registering file associations and more.

Possible candidates for this are:

- [NSIS](http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Main_Page)
- [InnoSetup](http://www.jrsoftware.org/isinfo.php)
- MSI package (the "official" Windows installer system)

Export templates may or may not be bundled (it will make the installer size grow significantly). They could also be downloaded in the installer, if the user chooses to install them.

As a bonus, we could also provide guidance or scripts for packaging Godot projects in Windows installers.

data.body: Im on OSX el captain **Issue description:** In https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/1105, the link in godot engines post redirects to the main github page itself, it isnt accessible anymore. **Steps to reproduce:** 1. data.title: App Menu missing the quit item so my application has been reject by Mac App Store !
data.body: **Operating system or device - Godot version:** MacOS Sierra - Godotengine 2.1.2 **Issue description:** My application build with Godoengine 2.1.2 is refused by Mac App Store. The reason the menu bar does not conform with apple applications because it lacks the quit menu. How to fix it ? Thank you. Mail from Apple: ------------------------ Before you Submit The user interface of your app is not consistent with the OS X Human Interface Guidelines. Specifically: We found that the App Menu is missing the quit item. Next Steps Please revise your app to address all instances of this type of issue. ------------------------ **Steps to reproduce:** Send app to Apple.

data.title: Call Func Track blocks transform Object when AnimationTreePlayer is playing in editor
data.body:
[I have created an example that shows this behavior.](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/849788/AnimationTreePlayer_lock_Object.zip)

When added to the animation test2 in example Call Func Track and AnimationTreePlayer is playing in editor transform player object is reset and blocked in game.
Call Func Track in root node blocks movement, body node blocks rotate.
If delete both track from test2 animation or stop playing AnimationTreePlayer in editor control is back in the game. In some cases stop playing AnimationTreePlayer in editor does not solve the problem.

In editor player object is blocked too when AnimationTreePlayer is playing.

I added to the example a cube that moves with keys WSAD, space jump and mouse rotate.
I hope that this example will help because otherwise I can not explain it.

data.title: Multiple mouse cursors support
data.body:
This is very low priority even for me as the issue-poster, but it could be cool I guess to support. This is not a duplicate of #8028 because in X11 multitouch events are separate from multiple cursors.

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
i3 + X11 + Debian + systemd + GNU + Linux / Godot 2.1.2

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
I enabled two mouse cursors on my desktop and started messing with the buttons in the Godot editor, leaving a button stuck in the depressed state.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1) Attach two mice to the computer
2) Follow the directions in https://ao2.it/en/blog/2010/01/19/poor-mans-multi-touch-using-multiple-mice-xorg to enable multiple cursors (no need to remap buttons though)
2.5) Open the Godot editor to some project
3) Move the cursors so that one is over the "stop" button and one is not over any button
4) Click and hold the cursor that is over the button
5) Click and release the cursor that is not over the button
6) Release the cursor that is over the button

data.title: Make Create New Node dialog resizable and burninate old dialog
data.body:
- "Create New (Node)" dialog is now resizable and stores its bounds (like the other dialogs I previously did). Renamed the `popup` method to be like in the other dialogs (distuingishable from the default `popup`).
- Trashed the commented out code of the old Create New dialog as the new one works fine since many months now.

data.title: skybox render issue
data.body:
skybox draws very ugly gradients. it can be easily checked by creating a gradient (even 2048 of size) and applying it as skybox. it will have very obvious transitions between steps (much more noticeable then it should be). enabling hdr does not help tho.
![gradient](http://i.imgur.com/ZXzI2vC.png)
and this thing also results in strange lightning.
![cube](http://i.imgur.com/EgLj90k.png)
  - from discord looked at the source of drawing procedure and said that it really needs reviewing.

data.title: Label has a gettable line_height property - what about RichTextLabel?
data.body:
<!--
README: Incompatibilities and broken features in the current master branch / 3.0-alpha
are known and expected due to important refactoring work, so no need to report them for now. Thanks!
-->

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1 stable, but applies to the current master branch too.

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Label has a convenient `line_height` property and `get_line_height` method; is there a specific reason RichTextLabel doesn't? I could see this being a little tricky since there's no guarantee every line will have the same height (ie, if the font is different or if an image is inserted, it might take up more vertical space), but it'd be nice if we could get either the height of a given line in the RTL, or the "default" line-height based on the RTL's normal-styled-text font options.

For context: I came across this while playing with the [Godot TIE addon](https://github.com/henriquelalves/GodotTIE), which adds a lot of cool functionality to a dialog-style interface. It uses labels for all its text; I wanted to try using RichTextLabels to gain access to multiple font styles, bbcode parsing, etc. But the addon uses `Label.get_line_height()`, so I was hoping to find an equivalent that works with RichTextLabel. Is this a reasonable request, or are there technical limitations?

data.title: Add the option to check if input was handled
data.body:
When working with a viewport you should call Viewport.input() to pass
the input, but if the input was unhandled you might also want to call
Viewport.unhandled_input() so that objects in the sub-scene can handle
the event. This adds a way to check if the input was handled so that you
know whether you should call Viewport.unhandled_input() or not.

data.title: Zstandard compression library
data.body:
Greetings!

I'm just raising a flag about an interesting (de-)compression library that could optimize any operations using compression features:

[Zstandard](https://github.com/facebook/zstd) from Facebook (BSD-licensed), see their comparison in their `README.md`.

I'm not sure about the platform portability but it deserves a quick check.
